summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New Orleans entered a final judgment on May 3, 2019, ordering the production of a public records request to a New Orleans-based intelligence agency.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in New Orleans, alleges that, on August 9, 2018, Laura Bixby made a request to the New Orleans City Attorney's Office (NOHSEP) for a writ of mandamus in order to produce a map and maps of the city's real time crime cameras. The court granted the request without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, and ordered the production and production of the maps.  In its order, the court entered a temporary restraining order, which prohibits the destruction of documents, including maps and records, from being distributed to the public. The order also prohibits the issuance of subpoenas or any other emergency relief.  According to the complaint, the Court's order also prohibited the destruction or destruction of any documents or records requested by the complaint.  On May 10, 2019 the SEC filed a complaint in the United States District Court in the Eastern District of Louisiana against Collin Arnold, seeking a permanent injunction, disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty. The complaint also alleges that Arnold violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and the registration provisions of Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4) of Exchange Act Rules 206(3) and 206 (4)-8 thereunder. The SEC seeks an injunction, an officer-and-director bar, and an order requiring the destruction, destruction, alteration, or alteration of any records in the possession of the SEC. The litigation will be led by Mr. Arnold and supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay.Â  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the FBI in this matter.
